title: Feds arrest 171 suspected members of drug cartel in New England, including 49 in Mass.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: DEA arrested 171 suspected Sinaloa Cartel members in New England, including 49 in Massachusetts, in late August.
Operation seized $1.3 million, 33 guns, and 244kg of drugs in New England from Aug. 25 to 29.
Nationally, DEA arrested 617 suspects and seized 420 firearms and over $11 million during the crackdown.

title: Holidays not on the “calendar”
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Floating holidays allow employees to take time off for personal, cultural, or religious events not on the standard holiday calendar.
Employers typically provide around 10 holidays annually, while floating holidays require advance requests and supervisor approval.
Full-time employees are usually paid for floating holidays; part-time employees may have unpaid options depending on company policy.

title: Stefon Diggs talked about his Patriots debut, and the respect he has for Mike Vrabel
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Stefon Diggs made his Patriots debut with six catches for 57 yards in a 20-13 loss to the Raiders.
Diggs reflected on ongoing recovery from a torn ACL and emphasized the need to improve after the defeat.
Diggs expressed respect for new Patriots head coach Mike Vrabel, praising his commitment and leadership.

title: Readers: What’s your favorite spot for apple picking?
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Readers can vote for their favorite apple orchards in Massachusetts to update Boston.com's guide for 2025.
Honey Pot Hill Orchards was voted the favorite in 2023 by Boston.com readers, with new contenders featured this year.
Notable orchards include Sunny Crest Orchards in Sterling, Hollis Hills Farms in Fitchburg, and Red Apple Farm in Phillipston.

title: Photos: Highlights from Day 2 at Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: The second day of the Seisiún Irish music festival took place at Suffolk Downs in Boston.
The festival featured performances by The Waterboys, Glen Hansard, The Pogues, and more despite rainy weather.
Fans donned ponchos to enjoy the performances, and The Pogues closed the festival Sunday night.

title: Mike Vrabel on Drake Maye, Will Campbell, and Bill Belichick’s comments about banning Patriots scouts
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Mike Vrabel criticized the Patriots' lack of complementary football in their 20-13 loss to the Raiders.
Vrabel stressed the need for a balanced game, highlighting concerns over quarterback Drake Maye's passing stats.
Vrabel expressed optimism about rookie tackle Will Campbell despite a costly fourth-quarter penalty.

title: Court puts reinstatement of cannabis commission head on hold
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A judge initially ruled that Cannabis Control Commission Chair Shannon O'Brien should be reinstated; the state filed an appeal.
Massachusetts Treasurer Deborah Goldberg fired O'Brien in 2024, citing misconduct; a judge called the dismissal unfounded.
Shannon O'Brien's reinstatement is on hold as the appeal process continues; her term is set to expire in August 2027.

title: Man charged with murder after woman, 38, found dead in Lynn, DA says
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: A 38-year-old woman was found dead in Lynn after police responded to a call on Newhall Street.
A 30-year-old Lynn man was arrested and charged with murder in connection to the woman's death.
The suspect is scheduled for arraignment on Monday in Lynn District Court, names have not been released.

title: Jakobi Meyers shuts down questions about trade request: ‘Happy to be a Raider’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Jakobi Meyers, in final contract year, recently requested a trade from the Raiders, which was denied by the team.
Meyers, despite trade rumors, expressed contentment with the Raiders and praised their 20-13 win over the Patriots.
Meyers returned to Gillette Stadium with 8 catches for 97 yards, viewing it as a homecoming with family present.

title: Tornado confirmed in Mass. town as powerful storm sweeps over region
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A radar-confirmed tornado touched down in Holden, Massachusetts, during Saturday's storm, according to the National Weather Service.
Severe thunderstorms affected the East Coast from Baltimore to northern Maine, with a tornado watch over most of Massachusetts.
Damage reports included fallen electrical lines and blocked roads in Holden, Paxton, and Holyoke; no injuries were reported.
